title: How to Avoid Eyebrow Piercing Scars

steps.title: Choose a quality piercer.
steps.content: Choose a quality piercer. The person doing your eyebrow piercing should be a trained professional. They should work in a sterile environment with sterile tools, know the proper piercing technique, be knowledgeable about the piercing industry and experienced in piercing eyebrows. You should feel comfortable with them and able to ask them any questions you have about the piercing. Check to see if the piercer is certified by the state and if the piercing facility is licensed by the state. Each state may have different guidelines for piercing certification.

steps.title: Choose a hypoallergenic piercing.
steps.content: Choose a hypoallergenic piercing. If you have a reaction to your piercing, then you could experience swelling and redness. You can avoid this reaction by making sure the piercing you choose is labeled hypoallergenic. Options include surgical stainless steel, titanium, niobium, or 14- or 18-karat gold. [1] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Wash your hands before touching your piercing.
steps.content: Wash your hands before touching your piercing. Germs and bacteria from your hands can quickly lead to infection. Use warm water and soap, scrubbing for at least 20 seconds. [2] X Trustworthy Source Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Main public health institute for the US, run by the Dept. of Health and Human Services Go to source

steps.title: Don’t play with your piercing.
steps.content: Don’t play with your piercing. Dirty hands are the primary cause of infection that leads to scarring. Avoid fiddling with your eyebrow piercing. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Avoid places where dust, dirt or cigarette smoke will be near your face.
steps.content: Avoid places where dust, dirt or cigarette smoke will be near your face. It will be harder for your piercing to heal if it gets contaminated. Cigarette smoke will slow the healing process because it constricts your blood vessels.

steps.title: Don’t use products that may irritate the piercing.
steps.content: Don’t use products that may irritate the piercing. Avoid products like makeup or lotion during the first six to eight weeks when your piercing is healing. Don't apply any product directly to your piercing. Other products to avoid include hair products, gels, creams and dyes.

steps.title: Don’t cover your piercing during the healing process.
steps.content: Don’t cover your piercing during the healing process. Your piercing needs to breathe. Do not cover it with your hair or a bandage during the first six to eight weeks of healing.

steps.title: Stay away from bodies of water.
steps.content: Stay away from bodies of water. Swimming pools, hot tubs, lakes, rivers, streams, oceans, and other bodies of water all harbor germs and bacteria that can infect your new piercing. Don't go swimming until your piercing heals. Otherwise, it could get infected. [4] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Avoid sleeping on a new piercing.
steps.content: Avoid sleeping on a new piercing. Your piercing can easily get caught on your bedding, which can potentially cause skin tearing. If this happens, it will be harder for your skin to heal, and it can more easily become infected. [5] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Clean your piercing with a mild soap in the shower daily.
steps.content: Clean your piercing with a mild soap in the shower daily. Use an antibacterial liquid soap with a neutral pH that won’t irritate your piercing. Allow your piercing to soak in the warm shower water for a few minutes before applying the soap. Carefully use your soap to remove any dirt from in and around your piercing. Be careful not to pick at or pull your scabs off when scrubbing with the soap. Allow your scabs to fall off on their own. Avoid using hydrogen peroxide or rubbing alcohol on a new piercing because they are too harsh and can irritate your skin. You should also avoid bacitracin and other ointments not prescribed by a doctor. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Use an antiseptic to prevent infection.
steps.content: Use an antiseptic to prevent infection. Clean your piercing with a cotton ball soaked in antiseptic after you get out of the shower. Your piercer may provide you with an antiseptic solution or suggest an antiseptic solution you can buy. Antiseptic solutions kill germs and help prevent infections.

steps.title: Apply warm water and antiseptic to your piercing before bed.
steps.content: Apply warm water and antiseptic to your piercing before bed. It’s important to clean your piercing before you go to bed each night. Soak a cotton ball in warm water and thoroughly clean your piercing. Soak a second cotton ball in antiseptic and wipe your piercing clean. Dry the piercing using a cotton swab or tissue.

steps.title: Clean your piercing with a saline solution once or twice daily.
steps.content: Clean your piercing with a saline solution once or twice daily. Apply the saline solution as necessary. If you are exposed to dirty environments or accidentally fiddle with your piercing, use the salt water mixture to clean it. [7] X Research source Dilute one tablespoon of salt in one cup of water by stirring vigorously. Dip a cotton ball into the salt water mixture until it is partially soaked. Apply the wet side of the cotton ball to your piercing and gently clean the area.

steps.title: Clean your piercing less often after the first two weeks.
steps.content: Clean your piercing less often after the first two weeks. After the first two weeks have passed, you can clean your piercing less often. Continue using the antibacterial, neutral pH, liquid soap to clean your piercing every time you take a shower. Also continue using the salt water mixture whenever your piercing gets dirty in between showers.

steps.title: Know that eyebrow piercings naturally grow out.
steps.content: Know that eyebrow piercings naturally grow out. Eyebrow piercings are not permanent, and they can be rejected by your body. Any piercing on flat skin will eventually migrate to the skin’s surface. An eyebrow piercing can last anywhere from a couple of months to a couple of years. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Remove your piercing as soon as you notice your hole is migrating.
steps.content: Remove your piercing as soon as you notice your hole is migrating. It is important to remove your eyebrow jewelry as soon as these signs appear to avoid scarring. If you notice the skin in between your piercing is thin or the area is red, shiny or peeling, it’s time to remove your jewelry. [9] X Research source If possible, contact your piercer to have them remove it.

steps.title: Wash the piercing area daily.
steps.content: Wash the piercing area daily. Use the antibacterial soap you used to clean your piercing to clean the area now that the hole is closing. Make sure all soap residue is removed after washing.

steps.title: Use a warm compress if your piercing has pus.
steps.content: Use a warm compress if your piercing has pus. Provide extra care to a piercing that has pus. Gently wash away the pus, and use a warm compress. If the infection doesn't clear within 2-3 days or gets worse, contact your doctor immediately.

steps.title: Avoid using products that may irritate the closing hole.
steps.content: Avoid using products that may irritate the closing hole. Products like makeup, gels, creams, lotions, dyes and hair products should be avoided in the area.

steps.title: Drink lots of water.
steps.content: Drink lots of water. Keep your skin healthy by drinking water, taking vitamins and eating right to help the skin to repair itself.

steps.title: Ensure the hole is properly closed.
steps.content: Ensure the hole is properly closed. When the eyebrow piercing has closed, your skin color will have returned to normal, with no redness. It can take about one to two months for a piercing hole to fully close. If you aren’t sure if the hole has closed, you can check with your piercer or a doctor.

steps.title: Apply anti-scarring cream.
steps.content: Apply anti-scarring cream. After the piercing hole has fully closed, apply anti-scarring cream daily for one month. Follow the application directions on the label of your specific cream. Some creams need to be used for six weeks before they are effective.
